titleStmt.title: M1-8, 4 of 10. [Anon: The loves & hates of the Elizabethans themselves...]. Holograph. In back [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 8-16. 9p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M1-8-4. [Anon: The loves & hates of the Elizabethans themselves...]. Holograph. In back [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 8-16. 9p.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p: The hates loves & hates of the Elizabethans themselves

Yet the The actual words of the that But Compared with their If we turn from the play to the model It is a strange experience, this strange The nobles, who spoke so It is strange to turn from the stage to the private house. On the stage,

p.s: Their inarticulateness is real They spoke with great difficulty at the court of

div.p:
Their own voices are scarcely audible scarcely to be heard. If we look into the heart of that great room when Elizabeth sat within her we can make outthe beautiful of a knight, of in , goes to Court becomes one of Elizabeth's maids of honour. The court was vows that he wil not "fail to
to fulfil your desire in playing the good shepherd & will to thy power defend this innocent lamb from the wolvish cruelty & foxlike subtlety of the tame beasts of this place..."
And then, by a married man, falls in love with her. And then Bit the No Then there is silence. Had The curtain lifts surprisingly at odd intervals. We see the The old [illeg.] is free to seduce the girl. Again there is solence. The girl falls in love with . Gossip says she wd. (would) dress up as a man in a large white cloak & [match?] meet the earl privately. Silence falls. Then she has home a parted.

She is taken home secretly by her father. Her mother cries "when a fresh [untaught?] is an [hoor?] "If it
had pleased God when I did hear her that she & I had been buried it had saved me from a great deal of sorrow & grief & her .. from .... such shame as never had Cheshire woman, .... Write no more to me of her"

But save for their sf But the drama of the abandoned girl moves in darkness. She moves through the court without speaking seen by an only by a She is solicited by ; seduced by without [dressed?] up as a man without opening her lips. We see her in the white cloak only through the eyes of one Mrs [Maeken?] who dwelt at the near Ludgate". And her single letter to her sister, only speaks ceremoniously of the passing of time. So She The letters are all The common speech
Facts, writing She

Her own [passes?], the disgrace, the humiliation of the family are all hidden under the flourishes & ornament, parables & similes. is quoted. Spring & summer: the frost that [illeg.] affection; the flower of a garden – the kn semblance naturally her, levity & laughter in their old metaphor; though the meaning – that the man is in love with the girl & wishes to [breed?] from her breaks here & again Spenser is quoted. Indeed, the poets have taken from the pen have made it impossible for simple squires & country ladies to write English And behind their florid decoration, their strained elegance, the men & women are [fallible?], crude, [barbal?]; seducing each other; the wolves & foxes of the court pray & raven. Only we The bastards are born. Reflections are [illeg.] [Why?] what

under cover of their flowery speech, the real & the & the Pembrokes remain unseen. We only know of the [exchange?] from the plays that were acted at in on the that they felt excited Anonymity has They too, like Mar the dramatist, are nameless. anonymous. Only But all But by a queer The The trappings are there. No generation had more anxiety to preserve the substance from decay. The tombs tombs They seem to pretend Their graves are immaculately. One They defy death with their great tombs. In life they eat prodigously. They wear clothes that are so heavy they can scarcely stand in them. The outer life is as [illeg.]: as great cloth of gold & marble can make it. But the passions that hunt in the heart are within are silent Until the dramatists speak for them on the stage, they themselves are silent.

p.s: A literature The nobles in the upper part of the house then supplied their liverie (livery) the players & the

div.p: Their attachment to the substance of the earth; their body; their the greed with which they acquire; their catalogues of property of furniture; their perpetual [illeg.] for their estates. This has survived, in inventories, in little supplicating places; in the For everything was their at th in the gift of individuals, the family It was the queen, or her nobles, who had the [personal?] of patronage. The The patron was in his prime. The book depended on his favour. And yet in no

age can there have been a deeper gulf between the writer & the society. The great who presumably Who is to whom a young poet has dedicated his sonnets? No body troubles to ask. It is not a matter of importance it seems in court circles. The plays are not discussed. The world of writers is too remote from the court. The loves & hates of these descendants of the jugglers & minstrels are too have no bearing upon the life of the nobles. And the reason may be that the early works of call for no breed no out comment. The reason may be that the dramatists were not destroying anything: If these The indignation that, after the [fun?] [illeg.]; then, the example created in 16th century , was in part the rage of those who felt that their won world was being [civilised?]. People Great The great might be mocked in some of the plays. The censor was [flush?] to control any irreverence. But the releas the public at the or the could not resent feel, as the public in the 19th century felt when was acted that a writer had arisen who was [distinguishing?] the old humbugs: who was refle se holding showing up society the unmoveable of society. And the after all, since prose was still half poetry, a no separate birth, but half that function of the writer had the critical spirit had no proper tool.

Then aAgain the curtain rises; & the shadowy insubstantial life that was smothered in th in , at [illeg.], invisible ought to of the country squire, of the maid of honour is visible to us is revealed. The all in a round, almost before we have had time to settle in our seats, we are in the thick of real powers: of love; of adultery of murder. Everything is on tip toe. The mute silent loves figures are seen in all their [bravery?]. The pressure of unexpressed emotion, of the things that has embodied itself into [illeg.], into the figures of and : in the adulterer; in the the supper is laid; the cards are on the table; & the husband sees his wife lying [always?], in the arms of her lover. We the old yellow pages, with their blanks, their riddles, their [suppressions?] that can no longer be deciphered, are give place to the outright downright speech. In the play light all is evident & [outspoken?]. In real life all is hidden & covered over suppressed: the And The playwright has some of [colour?] in

p.sup: all their concealed, all their suppressed [immediately?], as

div.p: Anonymity is fast dispersing. The play dramatist is becoming self [anxious?]. The play is coming to be the merits the And at some point, the the dramatist is emerging from the old juggler & the bear leader. He is becoming freeing himself from the compulsion of the audience. He is reserving A There is a The bodily, the actual, If the body must still dominate the little stage, if the actual must be before the eye, & the

p.s: bodies must move violently, killing, [kniving?], goint to bed,

Killing, [kniving?], going to bed, adultery must still be the staple of the play; but the staple of of the play is the staple there must be action; murder; violence; adultery. But by degrees the dramatist is freeing himself from the stage. He is adding to his resources. There are His limits are still repressive. There is

div.p:
And by degrees the dramatist sheds his anonymity. He separates himself from his audience.
He wins a freedom. Though the stage exacts with an in an ande in the to
He He wins the right sometimes to fame, in an [illeg.], sometimes to divert the mind from what happens, to the motives, the hidden passions. behind the action. What, he broods, in a of is the effect of mercy? – if, the sword is withheld if the adulterers are [empouted?] not with death, but with a guilty conscience? – and by degrees But The play has still its drag its the compulsion of what the of the plot. It still. But here the reader at some such point the reader is born: the close co actors dramatists close companion; the detached the reader, the human being who writes So by degrees, the reader too loses anonymity. The reading the As the plays comes faster & faster, as the curtin rises yet again & again – upon , , , , – the

reader puts off becomes mould differentiated, say [an note?]; author that is, as a great world in which this is relevant, that not. He chooses; discriminates. He is not And the reader becomes himself aware that there are not in this in the literature certain [connections?], things that explain, that it may be, light up the folds, give meaning to the house; curiosities; knick knacks: but also, the is what we recognise as time There are people – whatever we mean when, by some pattern of words, the [lot?] at the times, as the great plays emerge out of the mist, something that comes back to mind, in the [illeg.] of the night: words that come to our lips. How we are in sight of that we are coming into the current which is to sweep aside the antiquary, which is to crash over the

The reader indeed is soon to be [appreciated?]. This is one of the delights lures of the Elizabethans that they [revive?] the seer, the hearer, the actor in us. If by Our anonym At some point – it differs from age to age, – the reader is born; for in the And anonymity But what we have anonymity is a great power. It has made one is a great possession – a stage that has no writer the Elizabethan page: the has kept the Eth (Elizabethan) drama [vigour? vision?] unattached; it has given it a general [state?] vitality; a lack of personality; as
if all the [hours?] of the [19th?] century had been cut away from W. & [T?]. & J. G. & the B. as if we could [slip?] the lives; the [songs?]; the as a width, a bareness,

so that we forget something in ourselves when we read it. We It gives us another being. Only, as the unknown man who, it is said once [held?] houses at the door, becomes more & more dominant, as [wine?] we fallen & stumble: we have to

Anonymity h gave us the ballads; it gave us the songs; it gave us is a great preservative. To know nothing except what is essential: to waste no time prying & peeping: but to to be know nothing – who wrote Lud Sing Cuccu who wrote [Hilu Fan?] – who wrote the [sonnets?] of [loys?], [mirthful], who but wrote to [ful?] spring, dea love, death But That And the stage with its bodies, its actors, taking part for some time preserved this anonymous voice only until when the [senses?] of the age, its hoard of [unfilled?] patterns, the [illeg.] in the [armtials?] of maids of [him?] & [curtain?]; pressed so hard on the dramatist that he invented a speech that cd. (could) give voice to everything. Then, with , anonymity was destroyed.. Everything is known that can be known until the stage becomes too small to act the drama; & there is the book takes the place of the stage play.

p.sup: his weight of pause, the dumb like of the king held

div.p: , after all, has great privileges. He can is irrepressible. He is not responsible. He is not self conscious. He is free from infection. He can adventure & experiment. He can borrow. He can jest speak on & on. He can say what everyone feels: the common experiences are his. No one asks that he shall be idiosyncratic: that he shall stamp his [dull?] [illeg.] on the old feelings: He shapes

p.sup:
And Anon the dramatist also speaks himself. For the audience requires [feels?] still part of the play, insists on repetition: it must be [adu?] to sit, a shad [thorn?], have a story: & as poetry is told in poetry, it must have action: [suicide?]: adultery. The anticipation of the audience to the
Et (Elizabethan) play was [unfortunate?]. The words will not fit the speakers: the [illeg.], the [lapne?] confusion: no one feels what they say, the emotion is often plastered onto a inappropriate figures. But if one must have violence, how avoid this [illeg.]

div.p:
at a distance from the moment. Nobody cares what his own private experience is. And so the songs of repeat over & over again what that Gather ye flowers while ye may; Death is coming: Anon is never tired of celebrating the Rose; never & that his [illeg.] is white; he is a repetitious, co And since he is content to say go unnoted, we cannot pin him down, we cannot separate him from his song. He has thus an anonymous vitality, drawn from other bodies, a perennial, common vigour.
Nor is he dead in ourselves. The crude early dramas still persuade us to read – not to find for the story. What comes next? The fil dramatist Anon has little
care for the [Abound?] So we become anonymous, in the early literature. It is only later, when the pressure of emotion had ca strewn up words, as a the fingers of a the man at the cast letters out of the bubbling metal, that we lose this quality, to gain ––?–– everything it seems. For there flocking the curtain [gives?] on rising. And now it has risen on ; then on : on ; on & By that time, there is nothing left unsaid: the whole of this to test

The play has killed the stage. The stage has become too small to act this drama. Perhaps after centuries, the play will renew itself, with Mozart in the , as with in . It never lived again in England. The book, after that, takes the place of the play & the is dead for ever.
